Probabilistic Kernel Function for Fast Angle Testing

Kejing Lu1  Chuan Xiao1,2  Yoshiharu Ishikawa1
1Nagoya University  2Osaka University
Abstract

In this paper, we study the angle testing problem in high-dimensional Euclidean spaces and propose two projection-based probabilistic kernel functions, one designed for angle comparison and the other for angle thresholding. Unlike existing approaches that rely on random projection vectors drawn from Gaussian distributions, our approach leverages reference angles and employs a deterministic structure for the projection vectors. Notably, our kernel functions do not require asymptotic assumptions, such as the number of projection vectors tending to infinity, and can be both theoretically and experimentally shown to outperform Gaussian-distribution-based kernel functions. We further apply the proposed kernel function to Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search (ANNS) and demonstrate that our approach achieves a 2.5X ∼similar-to\sim∼ 3X higher query-per-second (QPS) throughput compared to the state-of-the-art graph-based search algorithm HNSW.

1 Introduction

Vector-based similarity search is a core problem with broad applications in machine learning, data mining, and information retrieval. It involves retrieving data points in high-dimensional space that are most similar to a given query vector based on a specific similarity measure. This task is central to many downstream applications, including nearest neighbor classification, recommendation systems, clustering, anomaly detection, and large-scale information retrieval. However, the high dimensionality of modern datasets makes efficient similarity search particularly challenging, highlighting the need for fast and scalable vector computation techniques.

Among the various similarity measures for high-dimensional vectors, the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, cosine distance, and inner product are the most commonly used in practice. As discussed in Norm_range_LSH ; norm-explicit-quantization ; peos , it is often possible to pre-compute and store the norms of vectors in advance, allowing these measures to be reduced to the computation of the angle (inner product) between two normalized vectors, thereby highlighting the central role of angle computation. On the other hand, in many real-world scenarios, we are not concerned with the exact value of the angle itself but rather with the outcome of an angle-based comparison, which is referred to as the angle testing. Specifically, given a query vector 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q and data vectors 𝒗𝟏subscript𝒗1\bm{v_{1}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒗𝟐subscript𝒗2\bm{v_{2}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v on sphere 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, typical operations include comparing ⟨𝒒,𝒗𝟏⟩𝒒subscript𝒗1\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v_{1}}\right\rangle⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ and ⟨𝒒,𝒗𝟐⟩𝒒subscript𝒗2\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v_{2}}\right\rangle⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩, or determining whether ⟨𝒒,𝒗⟩𝒒𝒗\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v}\right\rangle⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ⟩ exceeds a certain threshold. These operations, however, require computing exact inner products, which have a cost of O⁢(d)𝑂𝑑O(d)italic_O ( italic_d ) per comparison and become expensive in high dimensions. To address this, we aim to design a computation-efficient probabilistic kernel function K𝐾Kitalic_K that can approximate these comparisons with reduced cost and high success probability. In particular, we focus on the following two problems:

Problem 1.1

(Probabilistic kernel function for comparison) Given 𝐪𝐪\bm{q}bold_italic_q, 𝐯𝟏subscript𝐯1\bm{v_{1}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐯𝟐subscript𝐯2\bm{v_{2}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ⟨𝐪,𝐯𝟏⟩>⟨𝐪,𝐯𝟐⟩𝐪subscript𝐯1𝐪subscript𝐯2\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v_{1}}\right\rangle>\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v_{2}}\right\rangle⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ > ⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩, how can we design a probabilistic kernel function K⁢(⋅,⋅):𝕊d−1×𝕊d−1→RV:𝐾⋅⋅→superscript𝕊𝑑1superscript𝕊𝑑1RVK(\cdot,\cdot):\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\times\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\rightarrow\text{RV}italic_K ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) : blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → RV, where RV denotes the set of real-valued random variables, such that (1) the computation of K⁢(𝐪,𝐯)𝐾𝐪𝐯K(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) does not rely on the computation of ⟨𝐪,𝐯⟩𝐪𝐯\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v}\right\rangle⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ⟩, and (2) ℙ⁢[K⁢(𝐪,𝐯𝟏)>K⁢(𝐪,𝐯𝟐)]ℙdelimited-[]𝐾𝐪subscript𝐯1𝐾𝐪subscript𝐯2\mathbb{P}[K(\bm{q},\bm{v_{1}})>K(\bm{q},\bm{v_{2}})]blackboard_P [ italic_K ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > italic_K ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] is as high as possible?

Problem 1.2

(Probabilistic kernel function for thresholding) Given an arbitrary pair of normalized vectors (𝐪,𝐯)𝐪𝐯(\bm{q},\bm{v})( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) with an angle ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, and an angle threshold θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ, how can we design a probabilistic kernel function K⁢(⋅,⋅):𝕊d−1×𝕊d−1→RV:𝐾⋅⋅→superscript𝕊𝑑1superscript𝕊𝑑1RVK(\cdot,\cdot):\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\times\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\rightarrow\text{RV}italic_K ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) : blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → RV such that (1) the computational complexity of K⁢(𝐪,𝐯)𝐾𝐪𝐯K(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) is significantly lower than that of computing the exact inner product ⟨𝐪,𝐯⟩𝐪𝐯\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v}\right\rangle⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ⟩, and (2) K⁢(𝐪,𝐯)𝐾𝐪𝐯K(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) can reliably determine whether ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ is smaller than θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ with a high success probability?

Both problems have various applications. The goal of Problem 1.1 aligns with that of CEOs ceos under cosine distance (we will postpone the general case of inner product to Sec. 4), allowing the designed kernel function to be applied to tasks where CEOs is effective, such as Maximum Inner Product Search (MIPS) ceos , filtering of NN candidates Falconn++ , DBSCAN sDBSCAN , and more. On the other hand, the goal of Problem 1.2 is similar to that of PEOs peos , making the corresponding kernel function well-suited for probabilistic routing tests in similarity graphs, which have demonstrated significant performance improvements over original graphs, such as HNSW hnsw . In Sec. 4, we will further elaborate on the applications of these two probabilistic kernel functions.

Despite addressing different tasks, all the techniques ceos ; Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN ; peos mentioned above use Gaussian distribution to generate projection vectors and are built upon a common statistical result, as follows.

Lemma 1.3

(Theorem 1 in ceos ) Given two vectors 𝐯𝐯\bm{v}bold_italic_v, 𝐪𝐪\bm{q}bold_italic_q on 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and m𝑚mitalic_m random vectors {𝐮i}i=1m∼𝒩⁢(0,Id)similar-tosubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑖𝑚𝑖1𝒩0superscript𝐼𝑑\{\bm{u}_{i}\}^{m}_{i=1}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I^{d}){ bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and m𝑚mitalic_m is sufficiently large, assuming that 𝐮max=argmax𝐮𝐢|𝐪⊤⁢𝐮𝐢|subscript𝐮maxsubscriptargmaxsubscript𝐮𝐢superscript𝐪topsubscript𝐮𝐢\bm{u}_{\mathrm{max}}={\mathop{\rm argmax}_{\bm{u_{i}}}}|\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{u_{i% }}|bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_argmax start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, we have:

(1)

Lemma 1.3 builds the relationship between angles and corresponding projection vectors. Actually, 𝒗⊤⁢𝒖maxsuperscript𝒗topsubscript𝒖max\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u_{\text{max}}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be viewed as an indicator of the cosine angle 𝒒⊤⁢𝒗superscript𝒒top𝒗\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v. More specifically, the larger 𝒗⊤⁢𝒖maxsuperscript𝒗topsubscript𝒖max\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u_{\text{max}}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is, the more likely it is that 𝒒⊤⁢𝒗superscript𝒒top𝒗\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v is large. On the other hand, 𝒗⊤⁢𝒖maxsuperscript𝒗topsubscript𝒖max\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u_{\text{max}}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be computed beforehand during the indexing phase and can be easily accessed during the query phase, making K⁢(𝒒,𝒗)=𝒗⊤⁢𝒖max𝐾𝒒𝒗superscript𝒗topsubscript𝒖maxK(\bm{q},\bm{v})=\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u_{\text{max}}}italic_K ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) = bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a suitable kernel function for various angle testing problems, e.g., Problem 1.1.

However, Lemma 1.3 has a significant theoretical limitation: the relationship (1) relies on the assumption that the number of projection vectors m𝑚mitalic_m tends to infinity. Since the evaluation time of projection vectors depends on m𝑚mitalic_m, m𝑚mitalic_m cannot be very large in practice. Moreover, since Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN ; peos all used Lemma 1.3 to derive their respective theoretical results, these results are also affected by this limitation, and the impact of m𝑚mitalic_m becomes even harder to predict in these applications.

The starting point of our research is to overcome this limitation, and we make the following two key observations. (1) The Gaussian distribution used in Lemma 1.3 is not essential. In fact, the only factor determining the estimation accuracy of 𝒒⊤⁢𝒗superscript𝒒top𝒗\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v is the reference angle, that is, the angle between 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q and 𝒖maxsubscript𝒖max\bm{u_{\text{max}}}bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. (2) By introducing a random rotation matrix, the reference angle becomes dependent on the structure of the projection vectors and is predictable.

Based on these two observations, we design new probabilistic kernel functions to solve problems 1.1 and 1.2. Specifically, the contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

(1) The proposed kernel functions KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see eq. (2) and eq. (3)) rely on a reference-angle-based probabilistic relationship between angles in high-dimensional spaces and projected values. Compared with eq. (1), the new relationship (see relationship (4)) is deterministic without dependence on asymptotic condition. By theoretical analysis, we show that, the proposed kernel functions are effective for the Problems 1.1 and 1.2, and the smaller the reference angle is, the more accurate the kernel functions are (see Lemmas 3.2 and 3.3 ).

(2) To minimize the reference angle, we study the structure of the configuration of projection vectors (see Sec. 3.2). We propose two structures (see Alg. 1 and Alg. 2) that perform better than purely random projection (see Alg. 3), and we establish the relationship between the reference angle and the proposed structures (see Lemma 3.5 and Fig. 4).

(3) Based on KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we propose a random-projection technique KS1 which can be used for CEOs-based tasks ceos ; Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN . Based on KS2subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we introduce a new routing test called the KS2 test which can be used to accelerate the graph-based Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search (ANNS) peos (see Sec. 4).

(4) We experimentally show that KS1 provides a slight accuracy improvement (up to 0.8%) over CEOs. In the ANNS task, we demonstrate that HNSW+KS2 improves the query-per-second (QPS) of the state-of-the-art approach HNSW+PEOs peos by 10% – 30%, along with a 5% reduction in index size.

2 Related Work

Due to space limitations, we focus on random projection techniques that are closely related to this work. An illustration comparing the proposed random projection technique with others can be found in Sec. B.1 and Fig. 3 in Appendix. Since the proposed kernel function is also used in similarity graphs for ANNS, a comprehensive discussion of ANNS solutions is provided in Appendix B.2.

In high-dimensional Euclidean spaces, the estimation of angles via random-projection techniques, especially Locality Sensitive Hashing (LSH) IndykM98:approximate-nearest-neighbor ; Andoni2004:e2lsh ; AndoniI08:near-optimal-hashing , has a relatively long history. One classical LSH-based technique is SimHash simhash , whose basic idea is to generate multiple hyperplanes and partition the original space into many cells such that two vectors falling into the same cell are likely to have a small angle between them. In falconn , the authors proposed a different LSH-based technique called Falconn for angular distance, whose basic idea is to find the closest or furthest projection vector to the data vector and record this projection vector as a hash value, leading to better search performance than SimHash. Later, the authors in ceos employed Concomitants of Extreme Order Statistics (CEOs) to identify the projection with the largest or smallest inner product with the data vector, as shown in Lemma 1.3, and recorded the corresponding maximum or minimum projected value to obtain a more accurate estimation than using a hash value alone Falconn++ . Notably, CEOs can be used not only for angular distance but also for inner product estimation.

Due to its ease of implementation, CEOs has been employed in several similarity search tasks ceos ; falconn ; sDBSCAN , as mentioned in Sec. 1. Additionally, CEOs has been used to accelerate similarity graphs, which are among the leading structures for Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search (ANNS). In peos , by swapping the roles of query and data vectors in CEOs, the authors introduced a space-partitioning technique and proposed the PEOs test, which can be used to compare the objective angle with a fixed threshold under probabilistic guarantees. This test was incorporated into the routing mechanisms of similarity graphs and achieved significant search performance improvements over original graph structures like HNSW hnsw and NSSG nssg .

3 Two Probabilistic Kernel Functions

3.1 Reference-Angle-Based Design

Remarks. (1) (Computational efficiency) Both functions are computationally efficient. For KS1⁢(𝒒,𝒗)subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆𝒒𝒗K^{1}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ), H⁢S𝐻𝑆HSitalic_H italic_S and ⟨𝒗,H⁢𝒖𝒊⟩𝒗𝐻subscript𝒖𝒊\left\langle\bm{v},H\bm{u_{i}}\right\rangle⟨ bold_italic_v , italic_H bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ (1≤i≤m1𝑖𝑚1\leq i\leq m1 ≤ italic_i ≤ italic_m) can be pre-computed. Hence, for all 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v’s, we only need to determine ZH⁢S⁢(𝒒)subscript𝑍𝐻𝑆𝒒Z_{HS}(\bm{q})italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q ) online, which requires cost O⁢(d⁢m)𝑂𝑑𝑚O(dm)italic_O ( italic_d italic_m ) (This cost can be further reduced by a reasonable choice of S𝑆Sitalic_S. See Sec. 3.2). For KS2⁢(𝒒,𝒗)subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆𝒒𝒗K^{2}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ), AS⁢(H⁢𝒗)subscript𝐴𝑆𝐻𝒗A_{S}(H\bm{v})italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H bold_italic_v ) and ZS⁢(H⁢𝒗)subscript𝑍𝑆𝐻𝒗Z_{S}(H\bm{v})italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H bold_italic_v ) can be pre-computed. H⁢𝒒𝐻𝒒H\bm{q}italic_H bold_italic_q only needs to be computed online via Fast Johnson–Lindenstrauss Transform ACHash ; falconn once, with cost O⁢(d⁢log⁡d)𝑂𝑑𝑑O(d\log d)italic_O ( italic_d roman_log italic_d ), and ⟨H⁢𝒒,ZS⁢(H⁢𝒗)⟩𝐻𝒒subscript𝑍𝑆𝐻𝒗\left\langle H\bm{q},Z_{S}(H\bm{v})\right\rangle⟨ italic_H bold_italic_q , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H bold_italic_v ) ⟩ can be computed online with cost O⁢(L)𝑂𝐿O(L)italic_O ( italic_L ) for every 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v, where L≪dmuch-less-than𝐿𝑑L\ll ditalic_L ≪ italic_d denotes the number of partitioned subspaces and will be explained in Sec. 3.2.

(2) (Exploitation of reference angle) In the design of existing projection techniques such as CEOs ceos , Falconn falconn , Falconn++ Falconn++ , etc., only the reference vector ZS(⋅))Z_{S}{(\cdot))}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) ) is utilized. In contrast, our kernel functions defined in eq. (2) and eq. (3) incorporate not only the reference vector ZS(⋅))Z_{S}{(\cdot))}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) ) but also the reference angle information AS⁢(⋅)subscript𝐴𝑆⋅A_{S}(\cdot)italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) (although the reference angle is not explicitly shown in eq. (2), its influence will become clear in Lemma 3.2). In fact, the reference angle plays a central role, as it is the key factor controlling the precision of angle estimation (see Lemma 3.2).

(3) (Generalizations of CEOs and PEOs) Beyond incorporating the reference angle, these two kernel functions can also be regarded as generalizations of CEOs and PEOs respectively in a certain sense. Specifically, if S𝑆Sitalic_S is taken as a point set generated via a Gaussian distribution and ZS⁢(𝒗)subscript𝑍𝑆𝒗Z_{S}(\bm{v})italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) is replaced by the reference vector having the maximum inner product with the query, then KS1⁢(𝒒,𝒗)subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆𝒒𝒗K^{1}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) equals the indicator 𝒗⊤⁢𝒖maxsuperscript𝒗topsubscript𝒖max\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u_{\text{max}}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT used in CEOs. Similarly, if we remove the term AS⁢(H⁢𝒗)subscript𝐴𝑆𝐻𝒗A_{S}(H\bm{v})italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H bold_italic_v ) and take S𝑆Sitalic_S to be the same space-partitioned structure as that of PEOs, KS2⁢(𝒒,𝒗)subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆𝒒𝒗K^{2}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) is similar to the indicator of PEOs.

(4) (Configuration of projection vectors) Although we do not currently require any specific properties of the configuration of S𝑆Sitalic_S, it is clear that the shape of S𝑆Sitalic_S impacts both KS1⁢(𝒒,𝒗)subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆𝒒𝒗K^{1}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) and KS2⁢(𝒒,𝒗)subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆𝒒𝒗K^{2}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ). We will discuss the structure of S𝑆Sitalic_S in detail in Sec. 3.2.

Remarks. (1) (Discussion on boundary values) When ϕ=0italic-ϕ0\phi=0italic_ϕ = 0 or ϕ=πitalic-ϕ𝜋\phi=\piitalic_ϕ = italic_π, KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT take fixed values rather than being random variables, and when ψ=0𝜓0\psi=0italic_ψ = 0 or ψ=π𝜓𝜋\psi=\piitalic_ψ = italic_π, the exact value of ⟨𝒒,𝒗⟩𝒒𝒗\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v}\right\rangle⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ⟩ can be directly obtained. Therefore, probability analysis in these cases is meaningless. Additionally, in Lemma 3.3, we adopt the following convention: p2⁢(ϕ)=0subscript𝑝2italic-ϕ0p_{2}(\phi)=0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϕ ) = 0 if t′<0superscript𝑡′0t^{\prime}<0italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 0.

(2) (Deterministic relationship for angle testing) Lemma 3.2 establishes a relationship between the objective angle ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ and the value of the function KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Notably, after computing ZS⁢(⋅)subscript𝑍𝑆⋅Z_{S}(\cdot)italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ), the value of reference angle AS⁢(⋅)subscript𝐴𝑆⋅A_{S}(\cdot)italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) can be obtained automatically. Besides, as will be shown in Sec. 3.2, with a reasonable choice of S𝑆Sitalic_S, the assumption AS⁢(⋅)>0subscript𝐴𝑆⋅0A_{S}(\cdot)>0italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) > 0 can always be ensured. Hence, eq. (4) essentially describes a deterministic relationship. In contrast to the asymptotic relationship of CEOs, eq. (4) provides an exact relationship without additional assumptions.

(3) (Effectiveness of kernel functions) The above two lemmas show that, with a reasonable construction of S𝑆Sitalic_S such that the reference angle is small with high probability, KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can effectively address the corresponding angle testing problems. Specifically, the smaller the reference angle is, the more effective KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT become (By p2⁢(ϕ)subscript𝑝2italic-ϕp_{2}(\phi)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϕ ), a smaller ψ𝜓\psiitalic_ψ leads to a smaller p2⁢(ϕ)subscript𝑝2italic-ϕp_{2}(\phi)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϕ )).

(4) (Gaussian distribution is suboptimal) The fact that a smaller reference angle is favorable justifies the utilization of ZS⁢(⋅)subscript𝑍𝑆⋅Z_{S}(\cdot)italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) and also implies that the Gaussian distribution is not an optimal choice for configuring S𝑆Sitalic_S, since in this case, the selected reference vector with the largest inner product with the query or data vector is not guaranteed to have the smallest reference angle.

By the definitions of S¯msubscript¯𝑆𝑚\bar{S}_{m}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sm∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚∗{S}_{m}^{\ast}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, they correspond to the configurations that achieve the smallest expected value and the smallest maximum value of AS⁢(𝒗)subscript𝐴𝑆𝒗A_{S}(\bm{v})italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ), respectively. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, the optimal configuration Sm∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚∗{S}_{m}^{\ast}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is only known when m≤d+3𝑚𝑑3m\leq d+3italic_m ≤ italic_d + 3. In light of this, we provide two configurations of S𝑆Sitalic_S: one relies on random antipodal projections (Alg. 1), and the other is built using multiple cross-polytopes (Alg. 2). Each has its own advantages. Specifically, Alg. 1 enables the estimation of reference angles, while Alg. 2 can empirically produce slightly smaller reference angles and is more efficient for projection computation.

Before proceeding into the detail of algorithms, we introduce a quantity J⁢(S)𝐽𝑆J(S)italic_J ( italic_S ) as follows.

J⁢(S)=𝔼v∈U⁢(𝕊d)⁢[(AS⁢(𝒗))].𝐽𝑆subscript𝔼𝑣𝑈superscript𝕊𝑑delimited-[]subscript𝐴𝑆𝒗J(S)=\mathbb{E}_{v\in U(\mathbb{S}^{d})}[(A_{S}(\bm{v}))].italic_J ( italic_S ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_U ( blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) ) ] . By definition, J⁢(S)𝐽𝑆J(S)italic_J ( italic_S ) denotes the expected value of the cosine of the reference angles w.r.t S𝑆Sitalic_S. This quantity is consistent with our theory, as a random rotation is applied to 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v or 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q in eq. (2) and eq. (3). Based on the previous analysis, for a fixed m𝑚mitalic_m, J⁢(S)𝐽𝑆J(S)italic_J ( italic_S ) is minimized when S=S¯m𝑆subscript¯𝑆𝑚S=\bar{S}_{m}italic_S = over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is hard to compute. However, we have the following result to approximately evaluate J⁢(S)𝐽𝑆J(S)italic_J ( italic_S ).

Lemma 3.4

For every integer N≥1𝑁1N\geq 1italic_N ≥ 1, let v1,N,…,vN,Nsubscript𝑣1𝑁…subscript𝑣𝑁𝑁v_{1,N},\ldots,v_{N,N}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N , italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the vectors randomly and independently drawn from U⁢(𝕊d)𝑈superscript𝕊𝑑U(\mathbb{S}^{d})italic_U ( blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Lemma 3.4 shows that, when N𝑁Nitalic_N is sufficiently large, we can approximately evaluate the performance of different configurations S𝑆Sitalic_S’s by comparing their J~⁢(S,N)~𝐽𝑆𝑁\tilde{J}(S,N)over~ start_ARG italic_J end_ARG ( italic_S , italic_N )’s.

Now, we are ready to explain Alg. 1 and Alg. 2 as follows.

(1) (Utilization of antipodal pairs and cross-polytopes) We use the antipodal pair or the cross-polytope as our building block for the following three reasons. (1) Since all the projection vectors are antipodal pairs, the evaluation time of projection vectors can be halved. (2) Both of two structures can ensure that the assumption AS⁢(𝒗)>0subscript𝐴𝑆𝒗0A_{S}(\bm{v})>0italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) > 0 holds, such that the condition in Lemma 3.3 is always satisfied. (3) The result in antipodal-result shows that, for m=2⁢d𝑚2𝑑m=2ditalic_m = 2 italic_d, under mild conditions, the 2⁢d2𝑑2d2 italic_d vertices of a cross-polytope can be proven to have the smallest covering radius, that is, the smallest reference angle in the worst case. Although the results in the case m>2⁢d𝑚2𝑑m>2ditalic_m > 2 italic_d are unknown, we can rotate the fixed cross-polytope in random directions to generate multiple cross-polytopes until we obtain m𝑚mitalic_m vectors, which explains the steps from 6 to 10 in Alg. 2.

(2) (Selection from random configurations) We can generate such m𝑚mitalic_m points in the above way many times, which forms multiple S𝑆Sitalic_S’s. By Lemma 3.4, we can use J~⁢(S,N)~𝐽𝑆𝑁\tilde{J}(S,N)over~ start_ARG italic_J end_ARG ( italic_S , italic_N ) to approximately evaluate the performance of J⁢(S)𝐽𝑆J(S)italic_J ( italic_S ), and thus, among the generated S𝑆Sitalic_S’s, we select the configuration Spolsubscript𝑆polS_{\text{pol}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT corresponding to the maximal J~⁢(S,n)~𝐽𝑆𝑛\tilde{J}(S,n)over~ start_ARG italic_J end_ARG ( italic_S , italic_n ). This explains steps 5 and 11 in Alg. 2.

(3) (Accuracy boosting via multiple levels) Clearly, increasing m𝑚mitalic_m can lead to a smaller reference angle. The analysis in peos shows that, for certain angle-thresholding problems requiring high accuracy, an exponential increase in m𝑚mitalic_m, rather than a linear one, can be effective. Therefore, similar to peos , we use a product-quantization-like technique PQ to partition the original space into L𝐿Litalic_L subspaces (levels), which is adopted in both algorithms. By concatenating equal-length sub-vectors from these L𝐿Litalic_L subspaces, we can virtually generate mLsuperscript𝑚𝐿m^{L}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT normalized projected vectors. As will be shown in Lemma 3.5, the introduction of L𝐿Litalic_L can significantly decrease the reference angle.

(4) (Fast projection computation via multi-cross-polytypes) In eq. (2) and eq. (3), we need to compute H⁢𝒒𝐻𝒒H\bm{q}italic_H bold_italic_q, H⁢𝒗𝐻𝒗H\bm{v}italic_H bold_italic_v, H⁢S⁢𝒒𝐻𝑆𝒒HS\bm{q}italic_H italic_S bold_italic_q and H⁢S⁢𝒗𝐻𝑆𝒗HS\bm{v}italic_H italic_S bold_italic_v in the indexing phase or in the query phase. If such projection time is a concern in practice, we can set R𝑅Ritalic_R and L𝐿Litalic_L to 1 in Alg. 2 to accelerate the projection without the explicit computation of S𝑆Sitalic_S. Specifically, if m≥2⁢d𝑚2𝑑m\geq 2ditalic_m ≥ 2 italic_d, suppose that m𝑚mitalic_m is divisible by 2⁢d2𝑑2d2 italic_d and m=2⁢l⁢d𝑚2𝑙𝑑m=2lditalic_m = 2 italic_l italic_d. H⊤superscript𝐻topH^{\top}italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or (H⁢S)⊤superscript𝐻𝑆top(HS)^{\top}( italic_H italic_S ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be approximated by [S(1),S(2),S(l)]⊤superscriptsubscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2subscript𝑆𝑙top[S_{(1)},S_{(2)},S_{(l)}]^{\top}[ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where S(i)subscript𝑆𝑖S_{(i)}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT here denotes the i𝑖iitalic_i-th structured random projection matrix. By Alg. 1 and Alg. 2, we obtain structures Ssym⁢(m,L)subscript𝑆sym𝑚𝐿S_{\text{sym}}(m,L)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m , italic_L ) and Spol⁢(m,L)subscript𝑆pol𝑚𝐿S_{\text{pol}}(m,L)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m , italic_L ) virtually containing mLsuperscript𝑚𝐿m^{L}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT projection vectors. 4 Applications to Similarity Search

In Sec. 4, we show how KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be used in concrete applications.

4.1 Improvement on CEOs-Based Techniques

As for KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can use it to improve CEOs, which is used for Maximum Inner Product Search (MIPS) and further applied to accelerate LSH-based ANNS falconn and DBSCAN sDBSCAN . Since CEOs is originally designed for inner products, we generalize KS1subscriptsuperscript𝐾1𝑆K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to KS1′subscriptsuperscript𝐾superscript1′𝑆K^{1^{\prime}}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows to align with CEOs:

KS1′⁢(𝒒,𝒗)=‖𝒗‖⋅⟨𝒗,ZH⁢S⁢(𝒒)⟩𝒗∈ℝd,𝒒∈𝕊d−1.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝐾superscript1′𝑆𝒒𝒗⋅norm𝒗𝒗subscript𝑍𝐻𝑆𝒒formulae-sequence𝒗superscriptℝ𝑑𝒒superscript𝕊𝑑1K^{1^{\prime}}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})=\|\bm{v}\|\cdot\left\langle\bm{v},Z_{HS}(\bm% {q})\right\rangle\qquad\bm{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\bm{q}\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}.italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) = ∥ bold_italic_v ∥ ⋅ ⟨ bold_italic_v , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q ) ⟩ bold_italic_v ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_q ∈ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . It is easy to see that, with two minor modifications, that is, replacing 𝒗∈𝕊d−1𝒗superscript𝕊𝑑1\bm{v}\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}bold_italic_v ∈ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with 𝒗∈ℝd𝒗superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_v ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and replacing x𝑥xitalic_x with ‖𝒗‖⁢xnorm𝒗𝑥\|\bm{v}\|x∥ bold_italic_v ∥ italic_x in eq. (4), Lemma 3.2 still holds. Therefore, KS1′subscriptsuperscript𝐾superscript1′𝑆K^{1^{\prime}}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be regarded as a reasonable kernel function for inner products. Then, we can apply KS1′subscriptsuperscript𝐾superscript1′𝑆K^{1^{\prime}}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the algorithm in ceos ; Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN . We only need to make the following modification. In these algorithms, the random Gaussian matrix, which denotes the set of projection vectors, can be replaced by Ssymsubscript𝑆symS_{\text{sym}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Spolsubscript𝑆polS_{\text{pol}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with the other parts unchanged. To distinguish this projection technique based on KS1′subscriptsuperscript𝐾superscript1′𝑆K^{1^{\prime}}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from CEOs, we refer to it as KS1 (see Alg. 4 for the projection structure of KS1). In the experiments, we will demonstrate that KS1 yields a slight improvement in recall rates over CEOs, owing to a smaller reference angle.

4.2 A New Probabilistic Test in Similarity Graph

This is the original task of PEOs peos , where the authors introduce probabilistic routing into similarity graphs to accelerate the search. The definition of probabilistic routing is as follows.

Definition 4.1 (Probabilistic Routing peos )

Given a query vector 𝐪𝐪\bm{q}bold_italic_q, a node v𝑣vitalic_v in the graph index, an error bound ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ, and a distance threshold δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ, for an arbitrary neighbor w𝑤witalic_w of v𝑣vitalic_v such that d⁢i⁢s⁢t⁢(𝐰,𝐪)<δ𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡𝐰𝐪𝛿dist(\bm{w},\bm{q})<\deltaitalic_d italic_i italic_s italic_t ( bold_italic_w , bold_italic_q ) < italic_δ, if a routing algorithm returns true for w𝑤witalic_w with a probability of at least 1−ϵ1italic-ϵ1-\epsilon1 - italic_ϵ, then the algorithm is deemed to be (δ,1−ϵ)𝛿1italic-ϵ(\delta,1-\epsilon)( italic_δ , 1 - italic_ϵ )-routing.

In peos , the authors proposed a (δ,1−ϵ)𝛿1italic-ϵ(\delta,1-\epsilon)( italic_δ , 1 - italic_ϵ )-routing test called PEOs test. Here, based on KS2subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we propose a new routing test for ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distance, called the KS2 test, as follows.

Σi=1L⁢𝒒𝒊⊤⁢𝒖𝒆⁢[𝒊]𝒊≥AS⁢(𝒗)⋅‖𝒘‖2/2−τ−𝒗⊤⁢𝒒‖𝒆‖.subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝐿𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝒒𝒊topsubscriptsuperscript𝒖𝒊𝒆delimited-[]𝒊⋅subscript𝐴𝑆𝒗superscriptnorm𝒘22𝜏superscript𝒗top𝒒norm𝒆\Sigma^{L}_{i=1}{\bm{{q_{i}}^{\top}u^{i}_{e[i]}}}\geq A_{S}(\bm{v})\cdot\frac{% \|\bm{w}\|^{2}/2-\tau-\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{q}}{\|\bm{e}\|}.roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_e bold_[ bold_italic_i bold_] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) ⋅ divide start_ARG ∥ bold_italic_w ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 2 - italic_τ - bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_q end_ARG start_ARG ∥ bold_italic_e ∥ end_ARG . (10)

Here, 𝒒∈ℝd𝒒superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{q}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_q ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the query, v𝑣vitalic_v is the visited graph node, w𝑤witalic_w is the neighbor of v𝑣vitalic_v and e𝑒eitalic_e is the edge between v𝑣vitalic_v and w𝑤witalic_w. τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is the threshold determined by the result list of graph. 𝒒𝒊subscript𝒒𝒊\bm{q_{i}}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒆𝒊subscript𝒆𝒊\bm{e_{i}}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒖𝒋𝒊subscriptsuperscript𝒖𝒊𝒋\bm{u^{i}_{j}}bold_italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the i𝑖iitalic_i-th sub-vectors of 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q (1≤i≤L1𝑖𝐿1\leq i\leq L1 ≤ italic_i ≤ italic_L), 𝒆𝒆\bm{e}bold_italic_e and 𝒖𝒋subscript𝒖𝒋\bm{u_{j}}bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. 𝒖𝒆⁢[𝒊]𝒊subscriptsuperscript𝒖𝒊𝒆delimited-[]𝒊\bm{u^{i}_{e[i]}}bold_italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_e bold_[ bold_italic_i bold_] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the reference vector of 𝒆𝒊subscript𝒆𝒊\bm{e_{i}}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT among all {𝒖𝒋𝒊}subscriptsuperscript𝒖𝒊𝒋\{\bm{u^{i}_{j}}\}{ bold_italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }’s (1≤j≤m1𝑗𝑚1\leq j\leq m1 ≤ italic_j ≤ italic_m). In our experiments, S𝑆Sitalic_S is taken to be Ssym⁢(256,L)subscript𝑆sym256𝐿S_{\text{sym}}(256,L)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 256 , italic_L ).

During the traversal of the similarity graph, we check the exact distance from graph node w𝑤witalic_w to q𝑞qitalic_q only when ineq. (10) is satisfied; otherwise, we skip the computation of w𝑤witalic_w for efficiency. A complete graph-based algorithm equipped with the KS2 test can be found in Alg. 6. By Lemma 3.3 and the same analysis in peos , we can easily obtain the following result.

Corollary 4.2

The graph-based search equipped with the KS2 test (10) is a (δ,0.5)𝛿0.5(\delta,0.5)( italic_δ , 0.5 )-routing test.

Comparison with PEOs. Since PEOs also uses a Gaussian distribution to generate projection vectors in subspaces like CEOs, the estimation in ineq. (10) is more accurate than that of the PEOs test, as discussed earlier. In addition, the proposed test has two advantages:(1) ineq. (10) is much simpler than the testing inequality in the PEOs test, resulting in higher evaluation efficiency; (2) ineq. (10) requires fewer constants to be stored, leading to a smaller index size compared to that of PEOs.

Complexity analysis. For the time complexity, for every edge e𝑒eitalic_e, the computation of the LHS of ineq. (10) requires L𝐿Litalic_L lookups in the table and L−1𝐿1L-1italic_L - 1 additions, while the computation of the RHS of ineq. (10) requires two additions and one multiplication. By using SIMD, we can perform the KS2 test for 16161616 edges simultaneously. For the space complexity, for each edge, we need to store L𝐿Litalic_L bytes to recover 𝒒𝒊⊤⁢𝒖𝒆⁢[𝒊]𝒊superscriptsubscript𝒒𝒊topsubscriptsuperscript𝒖𝒊𝒆delimited-[]𝒊\bm{{q_{i}}^{\top}u^{i}_{e[i]}}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_e bold_[ bold_italic_i bold_] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, along with two scalars, that is, AS⁢(𝒗)⁢‖𝒘‖2/(2⁢‖𝒆‖)subscript𝐴𝑆𝒗superscriptnorm𝒘22norm𝒆A_{S}(\bm{v})\|\bm{w}\|^{2}/(2\|\bm{e}\|)italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) ∥ bold_italic_w ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 2 ∥ bold_italic_e ∥ ) and AS⁢(𝒗)/‖𝒆‖subscript𝐴𝑆𝒗norm𝒆A_{S}(\bm{v})/\|\bm{e}\|italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) / ∥ bold_italic_e ∥, which are quantized using scalar quantization to enable fast computation of the RHS of ineq. (10).

5 Experiments

All experiments were conducted on a PC equipped with an Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6258R CPU @ 2.70GHz. KS1 and KS2 were implemented in C++. The ANNS experiments used 64 threads for indexing and a single CPU for searching. We evaluated our methods on six high-dimensional real-world datasets: Word, GloVe1M, GloVe2M, Tiny, GIST, and SIFT. Detailed statistics for these datasets are provided in Appendix C.1. More experimental results can be found in Appendix C.

5.1 Comparison with CEOs

As demonstrated in Sec. 4.1, the results of CEOs are directly used to accelerate other similarity search processes Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN . In this context, we focus solely on the improvement of CEOs itself. Specifically, we show that KS1, equipped with the structures Ssym⁢(m,1)subscript𝑆sym𝑚1S_{\text{sym}}(m,1)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m , 1 ) and Spol⁢(m,1)subscript𝑆pol𝑚1S_{\text{pol}}(m,1)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m , 1 ), can slightly outperform CEOs(m𝑚mitalic_m) on the original task of CEOs, that is, k𝑘kitalic_k-MIPS, where m𝑚mitalic_m denotes the number of projection vectors and was set to 2048, following the standard configuration of the original CEOs. Since the only difference among the compared approaches is the configuration of the projection vectors, we use a unified algorithm (see construction of projection structure Alg. 4 and MIPS query processing Alg. 5 in Appendix) with the configuration of projection vectors as an input to compare their recall rates. From the results in Tab. 1, we observe that: (1) in most cases, KS1 with the two proposed structures achieves slightly better performance than CEOs, supporting our claim that a smaller reference angle yields a more accurate estimation, and (2) Spolsubscript𝑆polS_{\text{pol}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generally achieves a higher recall rate than Ssymsubscript𝑆symS_{\text{sym}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, verifying that a configuration closer to the best covering yields better performance.

5.2 ANNS Performance

We chose ScaNN Scann , HNSW hnsw , and HNSW+PEOs peos as our baselines, where ScaNN is a state-of-the-art quantization-based approach that performs better than IVFPQFS, and HNSW+PEOs peos is a state-of-the-art graph-based approach that outperforms FINGER FINGER and Glass. Similar to HNSW+PEOs, KS2 is implemented on HNSW, and the corresponding approach is named HNSW+KS2. The detailed parameter settings of all compared approaches can be found in Appendix C.1, and additional experimental results can also be found in Appendix C.

(1) Index size and indexing time. Regarding indexing time, after constructing the HNSW graph, we require an additional 42s, 164s, 165s, 188s, 366s, and 508s to align the edges and build the KS2 testing structure on Word, GloVe1M, GIST, GloVe2M, SIFT, and Tiny, respectively. This overhead is less than 25% of the graph construction time. In practice, users can reduce the parameter efc to shorten indexing time while still preserving the superior search performance of HNSW+KS2. As for the index size, it largely depends on the parameter L𝐿Litalic_L, which will be discussed later.

(2) Query performance. From the results in Fig. 1, we make the following observations. (i) Except for Word, HNSW+KS2 achieves the best performance among all compared methods. In particular, HNSW+KS2 accelerates HNSW by a factor of 2.5 to 3, and is 1.1 to 1.3 times faster than HNSW+PEOs, demonstrating the superiority of KS2 over PEOs. (ii) Compared with ScaNN, the advantage of HNSW+KS2 is especially evident in the recall region below 85%, highlighting the high efficiency of the routing test. On the other hand, in the high-recall region for Word, ScaNN outperforms HSNW+KS2 due to the connectivity issues of HNSW.

(3) Impact of L𝐿Litalic_L. The only tunable parameter in KS2 is L𝐿Litalic_L. Generally speaking, the larger L𝐿Litalic_L is, the larger the index size is. On the other hand, a larger L𝐿Litalic_L can lead to a smaller reference angle and yield better search performance. Hence, L𝐿Litalic_L can be used to achieve different trade-offs between index size and search performance. In Fig. 2, we show the impact of L𝐿Litalic_L on index size and search performance. From the results, we have the following observations. (i) The index size of HNSW+KS2 is slightly smaller than that of HNSW+PEOs due to the storage of fewer scalars. (ii) When d′=d/Lsuperscript𝑑′𝑑𝐿d^{\prime}=d/Litalic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_d / italic_L is around 16, HNSW+KS2 achieves the best search performance. This is because a larger L𝐿Litalic_L also leads to longer testing time and d′=16superscript𝑑′16d^{\prime}=16italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 16 is sufficient to obtain a small enough reference angle.

6 Conclusions

In this paper, we studied two angle-testing problems in high-dimensional Euclidean spaces: angle comparison and angle thresholding. To address these problems, we proposed two probabilistic kernel functions that are based on reference angles and are easy to implement. To minimize the reference angle, we further investigated the structure of the projection vectors and established a relationship between the expected value of the reference angle and the proposed projection vector structure. Based on these two functions, we introduced the KS1 projection and the KS2 test. In the experiments, we showed that KS1 achieves a slight accuracy improvement over CEOs, and that HNSW+KS2 delivers better search performance than the existing state-of-the-art ANNS approaches.

Appendix A Proof of Lemmas

A.1 Proof of Lemma 3.2

Proof: (1) For the first statement, due to the existence of random rotation matrix H𝐻Hitalic_H and symmetry, we only need to prove the following claim:

Claim: Let 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q and 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v be two vectors on 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that the angle between 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q and 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v is ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ. Let C𝐶Citalic_C be a spherical cross-section defined as follows.

C={𝒖∈𝕊d−1:⟨𝒖,𝒒⟩=cos⁡ψ}.𝐶conditional-set𝒖superscript𝕊𝑑1𝒖𝒒𝜓C=\{\bm{u}\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}:\langle\bm{u},\bm{q}\rangle=\cos\psi\}.italic_C = { bold_italic_u ∈ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : ⟨ bold_italic_u , bold_italic_q ⟩ = roman_cos italic_ψ } . (11)

A.2 Proof of Lemma 3.3

We consider the following four cases based on the value of cos⁡⟨𝒒,𝒗⟩𝒒𝒗\cos\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v}\right\rangleroman_cos ⟨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ⟩.

Claim: Let O,A,B,C𝑂𝐴𝐵𝐶O,A,B,Citalic_O , italic_A , italic_B , italic_C be four points ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This claim can be easily proved by elementary transformations. Since A⁢B→→𝐴𝐵\overrightarrow{AB}over→ start_ARG italic_A italic_B end_ARG is fixed and A⁢C→→𝐴𝐶\overrightarrow{AC}over→ start_ARG italic_A italic_C end_ARG follows the uniform distribution of a sphere in ℝd−1superscriptℝ𝑑1\mathbb{R}^{d-1}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, cos⁡α𝛼\cos\alpharoman_cos italic_α and cos⁡β𝛽\cos\betaroman_cos italic_β are random variables. ℙ⁢[KS2⁢(𝒒,𝒗)≥cos⁡θ]ℙdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆𝒒𝒗𝜃\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[K^{2}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})\geq\cos\theta]blackboard_P [ italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) ≥ roman_cos italic_θ ] =ℙ⁢[cos⁡β≥cos⁡θ⁢cos⁡ψ]absentℙdelimited-[]𝛽𝜃𝜓\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}[\cos\beta\geq\cos\theta\cos\psi]= blackboard_P [ roman_cos italic_β ≥ roman_cos italic_θ roman_cos italic_ψ ]
=ℙ⁢[cos⁡α≥cos⁡θ−cos⁡ϕsin⁡ϕ⁢tan⁡ψ].absentℙdelimited-[]𝛼𝜃italic-ϕitalic-ϕ𝜓\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}[\cos\alpha\geq\frac{\cos\theta-\cos\phi}{\sin\phi\tan% \psi}].= blackboard_P [ roman_cos italic_α ≥ divide start_ARG roman_cos italic_θ - roman_cos italic_ϕ end_ARG start_ARG roman_sin italic_ϕ roman_tan italic_ψ end_ARG ] . (23)

We further consider the following two cases.

Case 1’: 𝐜𝐨𝐬⁡ϕ≥𝐜𝐨𝐬⁡𝜽bold-italic-ϕ𝜽\bm{\cos\phi\geq\cos\theta}bold_cos bold_italic_ϕ bold_≥ bold_cos bold_italic_θ.

ℙ⁢[KS2⁢(𝒒,𝒗)≥cos⁡θ]≥ℙ⁢[cos⁡α≥0]=1/2.ℙdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐾2𝑆𝒒𝒗𝜃ℙdelimited-[]𝛼012\mathbb{P}[K^{2}_{S}(\bm{q},\bm{v})\geq\cos\theta]\geq\mathbb{P}[\cos\alpha% \geq 0]=1/2.blackboard_P [ italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) ≥ roman_cos italic_θ ] ≥ blackboard_P [ roman_cos italic_α ≥ 0 ] = 1 / 2 . (24)

Case 2’: 𝐜𝐨𝐬⁡ϕ<𝐜𝐨𝐬⁡𝜽bold-italic-ϕ𝜽\bm{\cos\phi<\cos\theta}bold_cos bold_italic_ϕ bold_< bold_cos bold_italic_θ.

By the properties of Beta distribution discussed in the proof of Lemma 3.2 and the property of symmetry of incomplete regularized Beta function, we have

Appendix B Supplementary Materials

B.1 Illustration of Random Projection Techniques for Angle Estimation

An illustration is shown in Fig. 3. In this figure, 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q represents a query and 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v is a data vector. For Falconn, if 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q and 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v are mapped to the same vector, they are considered close. For CEOs and KS1, the inner product 𝒗⊤⁢𝒖superscript𝒗top𝒖\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u, where 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}bold_italic_u is the projection vector closest to 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q, is computed to obtain a more accurate estimate of 𝒒⊤⁢𝒗superscript𝒒top𝒗\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v. The key difference between CEOs and KS1 lies in the structure of the projection vectors. While CEOs uses projection vectors sampled from a Gaussian distribution, KS1 employs a more balanced structure in which all projection vectors lie on the surface of a sphere. By applying a random rotation matrix and constructing a spherical cross-section centered at 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}bold_italic_q, we can establish the required statistical relationship between 𝒒⊤⁢𝒖superscript𝒒top𝒖\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{u}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u and 𝒒⊤⁢𝒗superscript𝒒top𝒗\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v.

B.2 ANNS and Similarity Graphs

As one of the most fundamental problems, approximate nearest neighbor search (ANNS) has seen a surge of interest in recent years, leading to the development of numerous approaches across different paradigms. These include tree-based methods [10], hashing-based methods [3, 20, 1, 4, 26], vector quantization (VQ)-based methods [19, 15, 5, 16], learning-based methods [17, 21], and graph-based methods [23, 27, 14, 13].

Among these, graph-based methods are widely regarded as the state-of-the-art. Currently, three main types of optimizations are used to enhance their search performance: (1) improved edge-selection strategies, (2) more effective routing techniques, and (3) quantization of raw vectors. These approaches are generally orthogonal to one another. Since the proposed structure, PEOs, belongs to the second category, we briefly introduce several highly relevant works below. TOGG-KMC[29] and HCNNG[24] use KD-trees to determine the direction of the query and restrict the search to points in that direction. While this estimation is computationally efficient, it results in relatively low query accuracy, limiting their improvements over HNSW[23]. FINGER[9] examines all neighbors and estimates their distances to the query. Specifically, for each node, FINGER locally generates promising projection vectors to define a subspace, then uses collision counting which is similar to SimHash to approximate distances within each visited subspace. Learn-to-Route [6] learns a routing function using auxiliary representations that guide optimal navigation from the starting vertex to the nearest neighbor. Recently, the authors of [22] proposed PEOs, which leverages space partitioning and random projection techniques to estimate a random variable representing the angle between each neighbor and the query vector. By aggregating projection information from multiple subspaces, PEOs substantially reduces the variance of this estimated distribution, significantly improving query accuracy.

B.3 Algorithms Related to KS1 and KS2

Alg. 4 and Alg. 5 are used to compare the probing accuracies of CEOs and KS1, while Alg. 6 presents the graph-based search equipped with the KS2 test.

B.4 Numerical Computation of Reference angle

Fig. 4 shows the numerical values of the lower bounds (the RHS of ineq. (8)) under different pairs of (m,L)𝑚𝐿(m,L)( italic_m , italic_L ). From the results, we observe that increasing L𝐿Litalic_L significantly raises the cosine of the reference angle, whereas a linear increase in m𝑚mitalic_m leads to only a slow growth in the cosine of the reference angle, which explains why we need to introduce parameter L𝐿Litalic_L into our projection structure.

Appendix C Additional Experiments

C.1 Datasets and Parameter Settings

The statistic of six datasets used in this paper is shown in Tab. 2. The parameter settings of all compared methods are shown as follows.

(1) CEOs: The number of projection vectors, m𝑚mitalic_m, was set to 2048, following the standard setting in the original paper [25].

(2) KS1: For KS1, L𝐿Litalic_L was fixed to 1, as multiple levels are not necessary for angle comparison. The number of projection vectors, m𝑚mitalic_m, was also set to 2048, consistent with CEOs. We evaluated both KS1(S=Ssym⁢(2048,1)𝑆subscript𝑆sym20481S=S_{\text{sym}}(2048,1)italic_S = italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2048 , 1 )) and KS1(S=Spol⁢(2048,1)𝑆subscript𝑆pol20481S=S_{\text{pol}}(2048,1)italic_S = italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2048 , 1 )).

(3) HNSW: M𝑀Mitalic_M was set to 32. The parameter efc was set to 1000 for SIFT, Tiny, and GIST, and to 2000 for Word, GloVe1M, and GloVe2M.

(4) ScaNN: The Dimensions_per_block was set to 4 for Tiny and GIST, and to 2 for the other datasets. num_leaves was set to 2000. The other user-specified parameters were tuned to achieve the best trade-off curves.

(5) HNSW+PEOs: Following the suggestions in [22], we set L𝐿Litalic_L to 8, 10, 15, 15, 16, and 20 for the six real datasets, sorted in ascending order of dimension. Additionally, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ was set to 0.2, and m=256𝑚256m=256italic_m = 256 to ensure that each vector ID could be encoded with a single byte.

(6) HNSW+KS2: S𝑆Sitalic_S was fixed to Ssym⁢(m,L)subscript𝑆sym𝑚𝐿S_{\text{sym}}(m,L)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m , italic_L ). The only tunable parameter is L𝐿Litalic_L, as m𝑚mitalic_m must be fixed at 256 to ensure that each vector ID is encoded with a single byte. Since the parameter L𝐿Litalic_L in KS2 plays a similar role to that in PEOs, we set L𝐿Litalic_L to the same value in HNSW+PEOs to eliminate the influence of L𝐿Litalic_L in the comparison.

C.2 KS1 vs. CEOs under Different Settings

In Tab. 1, we compared the performance of CEOs and KS1 using the top-5 probed projection vectors. Here, we varied the value of s0subscript𝑠0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Alg. 5 from 5 to 2 and 10, and present the corresponding results in Tab. 3 and Tab. 4, respectively. We observe that KS1(Spolsubscript𝑆polS_{\text{pol}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) still achieves the highest probing accuracy in most cases.

C.3 ANNS Results under Different k𝑘kitalic_k’s

Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 show the comparison results of ANNS solvers under different values of k𝑘kitalic_k. When k=1𝑘1k=1italic_k = 1, ScaNN performs very well on Word, GloVe1M, GloVe2M, and Tiny, which is partly due to the connectivity issue of HNSW on these datasets. In the other cases, HNSW+KS2 achieves the best performance.

C.4 The Impact of L𝐿Litalic_L on the Other Datasets

Fig. 7 shows the impact of L𝐿Litalic_L on GloVe1M, GloVe2M, and Tiny, which is largely consistent with the results in Fig. 2.

C.5 Results of NSSG+KS2

We also implement KS2 on another state-of-the-art similarity graph, NSSG [13]. The parameter settings for NSSG are the same as those in [22]. From the results in Fig. 8, we observe that NSSG+KS2 outperforms NSSG+PEOs on all datasets except for GIST, which indicates that the superiority of KS2 is independent of the underlying graph structure.
